verses.name: Remains: Aristo of Pella 1:4
verses.text: Aristo of Pella is supposed to have been a Jew, whose work was designed to help the failing Judaism of his country.

verses.name: Remains: Aristo of Pella 1:5
verses.text: Though his work is lost, alike the original and the Latin translation of one "Celsus," it seems to have been a popular tract among Christians of Cyprian's time, and the Latin preface is often suffixed to editions of that Father.

verses.name: Remains: Aristo of Pella 1:6
verses.text: The work of Aristo is known as the Disputation of Papiscus and Jason, and Celsus tells us that Jason was a Hebrew Christian, while his opponent was a Jew of Alexandria.

verses.name: Remains: Aristo of Pella 1:7
verses.text: Now, Papiscus owns himself convinced by the arguments of Jason, and concludes by a request to be baptized.

verses.name: Remains: Aristo of Pella 1:8
verses.text: Celsus, who seems to have been a heathen or an Epicurean, derides the work with scornful commiseration; but Origen rebukes this, and affirms his respect for the work.

verses.name: Remains: Aristo of Pella 1:9
verses.text: All this considered, one must think Aristo was "almost persuaded to be a Christian," and deserves a place among Christian writers.

verses.name: Remains: Aristo of Pella 1:10
verses.text: From the Disputation of Jason and Papiscus.

verses.name: Remains: Aristo of Pella 1:18
verses.text: Jerome likewise, in his Hebrew Questions on Genesis, says:  "In the beginning God made the heaven and the earth.

verses.name: Remains: Aristo of Pella 1:19
verses.text: The majority believe, as it is affirmed also in the Dispute between Jason and Papiscus, and as Tertullian in his book Against Praxeas contends, and as Hilarius too, in his exposition of one of the Psalms, declares, that in the Hebrew it is:  'In the Son, God made the heaven and the earth.

verses.name: Remains: Aristo of Pella 1:20

verses.name: Remains: Aristo of Pella 1:30
verses.text: Thus writes Origen:…in which book a Christian is represented disputing with a Jew from the Jewish Scriptures, and showing that the prophecies concerning the Christ apply to Jesus:  although his opponent addresses himself to the argument with no common ability, and in a manner not unbefitting his Jewish character.
